creator: noelgrandin@gmail.com
text:
I want to be able to specify multiple files across multiple disk volumes.
Currently, there is no way to do that (should of using multiple filelists, which is inelegant).

Example:

<filelist>
  <file name="C:\temp\temp1.dat"/>
  <file name="D:\temp\temp1.dat"/>
</filelist>

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text: Whatever you are trying to do can be satisfied using Ant 1.7+ resourcecollections.  Please read that section of the manual under "Concepts and Types" and refer any further usage questions to user@ant.apache.org.

creator: noelgrandin@gmail.com
text:
Agreed, it can be accomplished with resource collections. 

It just looks and feels pretty icky when I'm building a classpath that spans volumes to have this:

<union>
  <filelist>
  </filelist>
  <filelist>
  </filelist>
  <filelist>
  </filelist>
  <filelist>
  </filelist>
  ... etc.....
</union>

whereas filelist feels like a natural fit, and seems like it should do the job.

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text: you don't need any filelist at all, <file> itself is a resource that can be a child of <union> or <resources>

creator: noelgrandin@gmail.com
text:
Nope, doing this:

<union>
  <file name="V:\mylibrary.jar" />
</union>

results in this:

    [javac] Using modern compiler
dropping Z:\(unbound file resource) from path as it doesn't exist


doing this:

<union>
  <file basedir="V:\" name="mylibrary.jar" />
</union>

doesn't help either.

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text: Let's bring this to the userlist where it belongs and we'll figure it out.
